conclusion: Consider the force on each segment of the wire separately and then combine them.
The wire is bent into a ν shape with equal side lengths and an included angle of 60°.
The total length of the wire is 2l, so each side of the ν shape has a length of l.
The force on a straight segment of wire carrying a current I in a magnetic field B is given by F = I * L * B * sin(θ).
The magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the wire, so for each segment, θ = 90° and sin(90°) = 1.
Each segment of the wire has a length l.
For the left segment, F_left = I * l * B * sin(90°) = I * l * B.
For the right segment, F_right = I * l * B * sin(90°) = I * l * B.
The direction of the force on each segment can be determined using the right-hand rule.
Since the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane, the forces on the two segments will be perpendicular to the wire segments and in opposite directions.
The left segment will experience a force directed outward to the left, and the right segment will experience a force directed outward to the right.
The forces are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, forming an angle of 60° between them.
The resultant force can be found using vector addition: F_resultant = sqrt(F_left^2 + F_right^2 + 2 * F_left * F_right * cos(60°).
Substituting the values: F_resultant = sqrt((I * l * B)^2 + (I * l * B)^2 + 2 * (I * l * B) * (I * l * B) * 1/2).
F_resultant = sqrt(2 * (I * l * B)^2 + (I * l * B)^2).
The magnitude of the Ampere force received by the ν-shaped current-carrying wire is F = sqrt(3) * I * l * B.
